Graphical abstract The kinetics of guaiacol conversion over ReS2/SiO2 and ReOx/SiO2 catalysts in a batch reactor at 300°C and 5MPa hydrogen pressure was studied. The ReOx/SiO2 catalyst was more active and selective towards deoxygenated products (mainly cyclohexane), while the ReS2/SiO2 catalyst was more selective towards the formation of phenol. Langmuir–Hinshelwood kinetic models were developed in order to identify changes in the reaction mechanism with the ReOx/SiO2 and ReS2/SiO2 catalysts. The results for the guaiacol conversion over ReS2/SiO2 catalyst were fitted to a model that assumes the presence of two different kinds of active sites and that hydrogen adsorption is generated through heterolytic dissociation. The conversion of guaiacol over the ReOx/SiO2 catalyst was fitted to a model that assumes hydrogen adsorption via homolytic dissociation and a single catalytic site. Keywords Kinetic Hydrodeoxygenation 2-methoxyphenol ReS2 ReOx Langmuir–Hinshelwood 1 Introduction Biomass has been considerably investigated as a new promising source for fuels and chemicals due to environmental concerns and the need to decrease the overdependence on fossil fuels. Pyrolysis of lignocellulosic biomass leads to compounds which have the potential to constitute an alternative source of fuel (bio-oil) and value-added chemicals [1–4]. Valorization of biomass is based on the production of chemicals like phenols or aromatics (BTX: benzene, toluene, xylene) from the lignin polyphenolic structure [5]. However, the pyrolytic bio-oils need to be upgraded before direct application as fuel due to the high content of oxygenated compound. Besides, the use of lignocellulosic compounds as a precursor of carbonaceous materials has gained interest due to its low cost and high availability [5–8]. Catalytic hydrodeoxygenation (HDO) has been demonstrated as an interesting and effective route to improve the properties of biomass-derived oil. The main oxygenated compounds in bio-oil originate from the lignin component of biomass. For that reason, guaiacol (2-methoxyphenol) has been studied as a lignin-derived model compound in order to elucidate the reaction pathway and the efficiency of the HDO process [9–12]. Conventional hydrotreating catalysts such as CoMoS, NiMoS, and MoS2 have been found to be highly active for the conversion of guaiacol. However, sulfide catalysts generally suffer from continuous deactivation whose origin has been linked to the formation of coke or partial re-oxidation of the sulfide phase [13–15]. Other promising catalysts are the Ni-based catalysts studied by Bykova et al. [9]. These researchers found that the most active catalysts among their library of catalysts in the HDO of guaiacol were Ni-based catalysts prepared by a sol–gel method and stabilized with SiO2 and ZrO2 supports. According to TPR, XRD, and HRTEM analyses, the high activity of these catalysts were due to the high nickel loading and the high specific area of active component as a result of the formation of nickel oxide-silicate species. These studies demonstrated the importance of exploring other active phases beside metals, oxides and conventional sulfides to improve the catalytic upgrading process. Among unconventional supported metal sulfide catalysts, ReS2 catalysts have been demonstrated to display a higher catalytic activity than a commercial sulfided NiMo/Al2O3 catalyst for the conversion of guaiacol [16,17]. Recently, Leiva et al. [18] found that ReOx/SiO2 catalyst displayed a higher activity for guaiacol conversion and a higher selectivity towards deoxygenated compounds in comparison with ReS2/SiO2 and commercial NiMo/Al2O3 catalysts. On the other hand, reaction networks for guaiacol conversion have been widely reported for different catalysts [13,15,19–21]; however, a fundamental understanding of the reaction mechanisms is still lacking. Studying the kinetics and reaction mechanism of furfural hydrogenation over Cu/SiO2 catalysts, Sitthisa et al. [22] found that the transformation of furfural over these solids followed a Langmuir–Hinshelwood model assuming: (1) dissociative adsorption of hydrogen, (2) that all adsorption sites are equivalent and independent of coverage, and (3) that the surface reaction is the rate-determining step. On the other hand, when Badawi et al. [23] studied the hydrogenation of olefins over sulfide catalysts and used the Langmuir–Hinshelwood theory, they obtained a pseudo Eley–Rideal model instead, after some approximations in agreement with the proposal by Sitthisa et al. [22]. In addition, Badawi et al. [23] proposed, by theoretical studies, that the adsorption of olefin is only possible on metal anionic vacancy, while the reactant H2 is heterolytically dissociated on the sulfide catalyst. The authors then concluded that the hydrogenation reaction occurred only on the sulfide phase, in agreement with the mechanism previously proposed by Olguin Orozco and Vrinat [24]. In our previous study, we compared ReOx/SiO2 and ReS2/SiO2 catalysts and correlated the difference in activity to results obtained from XPS. The pre- and post-reaction XPS results showed an increase in the amount of surface ReOx sites, consequently leading to comparatively higher activity. In contrast, the lower activity of ReS2 catalysts was attributed to decrease in dispersion caused by sintering. However, a greater understanding of the kinetics involved in the conversion of guaiacol is still lacking. Therefore, the objective of this study is to compare the behaviors of ReS2/SiO2 and ReOx/SiO2 catalysts during guaiacol conversion. In contrasts to sulfide catalysts which have been extensively studied in this kind of reactions [13–17,19,23–30], oxides catalysts and especially Re oxides have rarely been investigated. The results obtained for ReS2/SiO2 and ReOx/SiO2 catalysts in this study indicated large differences in activity and selectivity. To explain those results, the reaction was modeled using a Langmuir–Hinshelwood-type theory in order to identify changes in the reaction mechanism for ReS2/SiO2 and ReOx/SiO2 catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The catalysts were prepared by incipient wetness impregnation of an aqueous solution of NH4ReO4 (Aldrich, 99%) on SiO2 support (Grace Davison 432). A Re nominal loading of 2.7 atoms of Re per nm2 of support was the target. The impregnated catalysts were left for maturation at room temperature for 24h, dried at 393K for 12h and then calcined at 573K for 0.5h. The calcined sample was denoted as ReOx/SiO2 catalyst; in addition, a small portion of the calcined sample was sulfided at 673K for 4h under 15% H2S/N2 mixture and denoted as ReS2/SiO2 catalyst. These catalysts were characterized by N2 adsorption, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), temperature programmed reduction (TPR) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) in our previous studies [18]. 2.2 Catalytic tests HDO of guaiacol was carried out in a 0.25L batch reactor equipped with a hollow-shaft 6-bladed mechanically driven turbine with four baffles on the wall of the reactor to prevent vortex formation (model Parr 4841). The liquid reactant feed, consisting of guaiacol (0.232molL−1) in n-dodecane (80mL) with hexadecane (0.0341molL−1) as an internal standard, was introduced into the reactor. Approximately 0.200g of catalyst with a particle size of 100 mesh was added. The system was closed and, to avoid any air contamination, N2 was bubbled through the solution for 10min. Still under N2 the reactor was heated to the reaction temperature of 573K under stirring. The pressure was adjusted to 5MPa by H2 introduction into the reactor and kept constant during the course of the experiment with a stirring rate of 645rpm. Under these experimental conditions, the reaction was not controlled by diffusional effects and the reaction was under kinetic control [25]. Liquid samples were taken periodically during the reaction. The reaction products were identified by gaseous chromatography (PerkinElmer—Clarus 680) coupled to MS-SQ8T equipped and quantified by gas chromatograph (PerkinElmer—Clarus 400) using a flame ionization detector (FID) and a CP-Sil 5 column (Agilent, 30m×0.53mm×1.0mm film thickness). For the kinetic study, the initial concentration of guaiacol was varied from 0.09 to 0.45molL−1. Catalytic activity on guaiacol conversion was expressed in terms of the initial reaction rate calculated from the initial slope of the conversion vs. time plot, according to the following equation: (1) r s = [ b × n ] m where r s is the specific rate expressed in molg−1 s−1, b is the initial slope of the conversion of guaiacol vs. time (t/t), n is the initial number moles of guaiacol, and m is the mass of catalyst (g). The deoxygenation (HDO) rate was calculated from guaiacol conversion to O-free compounds (benzene, cyclohexane, cyclohexene, and analogs). On the other hand, the selectivities (%) were determined at 20% and 60% of guaiacol conversion, according to Eq. (2). (2) S % = X i X T × 100 where X i is the percentage of product i formed and X T is the guaiacol conversion. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 Catalytic activity Fig. 1 shows the total and hydrodeoxygenation initial rates of the conversion of guaiacol over the ReS2/SiO2 and ReOx/SiO2 catalysts. As can be observed, the ReOx/SiO2 catalyst was the more active catalyst, in agreement with our previous results [18]. Moreover, in our previous work, it was found that the ReOx/SiO2 catalyst exhibited higher total and hydrodeoxygenation initial rates of 2.9–4.8 times, respectively, than a conventional NiMoS/Al2O3 catalyst, demonstrating the potential of ReOx/SiO2 catalyst for the valorization of lignin-derived compounds. Fig. 2 shows the conversion and yield of products obtained for the transformation of guaiacol over the ReS2/SiO2 and ReOx/SiO2 catalysts as a function of time. These results show a clear difference between the catalysts. The main products with the ReS2/SiO2 catalyst were phenol, catechol, and cyclohexane (Fig. 2(a)). Catechol, detected in small quantities, was an intermediate product. Other compounds such as anisole, methylphenol, cyclohexanol, cyclohexane, and methanol were also detected in minor quantities, while- methoxycyclohexanone, hexane, cyclohexene, methylcyclohexane, and BTX (benzene, toluene, and xylene) were detected in trace amounts. With the ReOx/SiO2 catalyst (Fig. 2(b)), phenol, anisole, and cyclohexanol were the main intermediate products which led to the production of cyclohexane and BTX at higher conversions. Methylcyclohexane, methoxycyclohexanone, and methanol were the minor products obtained, while methylphenol, cyclohexene, methylcyclohexanone, and hexane were only detected as traces. In addition to these observations, the ReOx/SiO2 catalyst achieved a maximum conversion after 2h (∼80%) and then remained relatively constant over the course of the reaction. However, after less than 2h of reaction the concentrations of phenol, anisole, and cyclohexanol began to decrease while guaiacol conversion was about 60%. This is due to the competitive adsorption occurring between guaiacol and these products on the catalytic site. Fig. 3 shows the network of guaiacol conversion in agreement with Laurent and Delmon [13,26], Bui et al. [15] and Leiva et al. [18]. On the basis of this network, guaiacol is mainly converted to phenol via two pathways: a demethoxylation (DMO) pathway without catechol as an intermediate and a demethylation (DME) route to form catechol, which subsequently undergoes hydrogenolysis to form phenol. However, over the ReOx/SiO2 catalyst phenol was formed at low conversion (without going through the DME route) and rapidly transformed to products, including BTX (mainly benzene) and cyclohexane. The absence of catechol in the product stream could be due to its rapid transformation to phenol. Table 1 shows the products distribution calculated at 20–60% of guaiacol conversion: both catalysts were highly effective in converting guaiacol into phenol (60–75% selectivity at 20% of guaiacol conversion). Also, at 20% of guaiacol conversion, the ReOx/SiO2 catalyst displayed higher amounts of deoxygenated products such as benzene and cyclohexane than the ReS2/SiO2 catalyst. Furthermore, catechol was detected in higher amount with the ReS2/SiO2 catalyst. These results suggest that ReS2/SiO2 and ReOx/SiO2 catalysts have different active sites and acidic properties. In order to clarify these differences, the products distribution was calculated at 60% of guaiacol conversion, where the conversion was still linear with the time. There were clear differences observed at this higher conversion as can be seen in Table 1. The ReS2/SiO2 catalyst was highly selective towards phenol formation (75%), while the ReOx/SiO2 catalyst presented a higher distribution of products such as BTX (17.5%), cyclohexane (28%), and phenol (34%). This further illustrates that the transformation of guaiacol over ReS2/SiO2 and ReOx/SiO2 catalysts clearly follows different kind of mechanisms. Besides, the differences observed for the selectivities confirm that both ReS2/SiO2 and ReOx/SiO2 systems have different active sites which were not modified during the course of the reaction under our operating conditions. 3.2 Effect of guaiacol concentration With the objective to clarify and understand the previous reactivity results, the effect of guaiacol concentration over ReS2/SiO2 and ReOx/SiO2 catalysts was studied. The results obtained are shown in Fig. 4 which illustrates the variation of the initial rate as a function of guaiacol concentration over ReS2/SiO2 and ReOx/SiO2 catalysts. There was a fairly linear increase in the initial rate with the concentration of guaiacol over the ReS2/SiO2 catalysts. On the contrary, the initial rates over the ReOx/SiO2 catalyst increased up to guaiacol concentration of 0.183molL−1 and then decreased. These results confirm that the reaction mechanisms involved over the ReS2/SiO2 and ReOx/SiO2 catalysts are different. 3.3 Mechanism and rate equation In order to get more information on the reaction mechanism involved in the conversion of guaiacol over ReS2/SiO2 and ReOx/SiO2 catalysts, two kinetic models based on Langmuir–Hinshelwood concept were proposed. 3.3.1 Mechanism and rate equation over ReS2/SiO2 Various types of adsorption of dihydrogen are considered for hydrogenation reactions are in the literature, such as non-dissociative or homolytic dissociative adsorption which are expected to occur on metal catalysts [23]. In general, kinetic models for hydrotreating reactions differ by: (1) the use of one or two types of sites, and (2) the molecular adsorption or the homolytic dissociation of hydrogen [30]. However, over sulfide catalysts, adsorption mechanisms are thought to be different [23,30]. The mechanism over sulfide catalysts has been widely studied for hydrogenation and hydrodesulfurization reactions [24,27–29]. The kinetic models for these kinds of reactions as previously mentioned are often based on the molecular adsorption of H2 and H2S and sometimes on their homolytic dissociation [23,24,27]. However, it has been demonstrated in several studies that the reaction mechanism over sulfide catalysts involved the existence of two different catalytic sites and a heterolytic dissociative adsorption of hydrogen [22–24,28 and 30]. These active sites correspond to a coordinatively unsaturated metal ion and a strongly bonded stable sulfur ion under the experimental conditions studied [23,24,30]. On the basis of these studies, we propose a mechanism for guaiacol conversion over ReS2/SiO2 in accordance with the reaction network given in Fig. 3. This mechanism designated as Model 1 involves two active sites denoted as M=metal ion vacancy and X2− −M=sulfur stable ion. The set of elementary steps considered in Model 1 was identical to the one previously developed by Kasztelan and Guillaume [30] and Olguin Orozco and Vrinat [24]. In addition, this model was expressed in terms of the initial reaction rate, where the principal reaction products over ReS2/SiO2 catalysts were phenol and methanol. The set of elementary steps considered in Model 1 was: (3) Adsorption of GUA: GUA+M↔GUA−M Equilibrium K GUA (4) H2 dissociative adsorption: H2 +M+ X 2− −M↔H− −M+H+ − X 2−M Equilibrium K H2 (5) Addition of H−: GUA−M+H− −M↔GUAH− −M+M Equilibrium K 3 (6) Addition of H+: GUAH− −M+H+ − X 2− −M→Ph+MeOH+2M Rate constant K 4 The rate determining step was considered to be the second catalyst’s H+ attack on the oxygen of the methoxy group according to numerous researches [24,30–32]. The adsorption and desorption of reactants (H2 and guaiacol) are much faster than the surface reaction step and are assumed to be in equilibrium. The number of active sites is assumed to be constant, while desorption of the products and the adsorption–desorption of the solvent were not considered [23]. The development of the kinetic law assumed a weak H2 adsorption on metal active sites [24], and hence the coverage of proton and hydride species on the surface of the catalyst is lower than the coverage of guaiacol. Thus, the reaction rate for Model 1 is given by the expression: (7) r GUA = k 4 C GUAH − − M C H + − X 2 − − M From Eqs. (5) and (4), we can deduce the concentration of C GUAH − −M and C H + − X 2− −M, respectively. (8) C GUAH − − M = K 3 C H − − M C GUA − M C M (9) C H + − X 2 − − M = K H 2 C H 2 C X 2 − − M C M C H − − M Substituting Eqs. (8) and (9) into (7): (10) r GUA = k 4 K H 2 K 3 C H 2 C X 2 − − M C GUA − M From Eq. (3) the concentration of C GUA−M can be deduced and substituted into Eq. (20): (21) 1 r GUA = 1 k GUA C H 2 + 1 k GUA K GUA C H 2 C GUA 3.3.1.1 Corroboration of the kinetic model over ReS2/SiO2 In order to corroborate the kinetic law for the conversion of guaiacol over the ReS2/SiO2 catalyst, the initial rate values from linearized equation, as a function of the initial guaiacol concentration, were plotted in Fig. 5 , according to Model 1 (Eq. (21)). According to Model 1, the results must be adjusted to a straight line with positive a slope. Fig. 5 clearly shows that the conversion of guaiacol over the ReS2/SiO2 catalyst can fit the equation for Model 1 which follows a linear behavior and a correlation of 0.99645, similar to the classical Langmuir–Hinshelwood kinetic model. This result confirms the presence of two different active sites on the sulfide catalysts as has been previously proposed by Kasztelan and Guillaume [30], Badawi et al. [23] and Olguin Orozco and Vrinat [24]. For the ReOx/SiO2 catalyst, the catalytic activity results did not fit the equation for Model 1 (inset of Fig. 5), suggesting that the ReOx/SiO2 catalyst followed another kind of mechanism for the conversion of guaiacol. 3.3.2 Mechanism and rate equation over ReOx/SiO2 As previously stated, kinetic models for hydrotreating reactions involves either one or two catalytic sites as well as either molecular adsorption of hydrogen or homolytic dissociation of hydrogen [30]. Dissociative adsorption of hydrogen occurs relatively easily on many metals. On metal oxides, however, dissociation of the strong HH bond seems only to occur on the most reactive surfaces and is promoted by the presence of surface defects. Homolytic dissociative adsorption results in two hydroxyls or, less commonly, two metal-hydrogen species. Heterolytic adsorption is also possible; however, the metal-hydrides formed are not very stable species, and so the more general route is the formation of hydroxyl groups [33,34]. Unlike sulfide catalysts, the oxide catalysts have been less studied for these kinds of reaction. As discussed earlier, the Re oxide catalyst follows a kinetic model which differs from the Re sulfide catalyst for the reaction under study. Therefore, the mechanism proposed for this catalyst is designated as Model 2 and assumes the presence of one kind of active sites designated as M and hydrogen adsorption by homolytic dissociation. This active site can be associated with the metal oxide defects created by hydrogen attack, generating H2O removal on the ReOx/SiO2 catalyst [18]. Furthermore, in our previous work [18], we showed by XPS analysis of the post-reaction ReOx/SiO2 catalyst that in-situ partial reduction of around 10% of the oxide phase occurred after 4h of reaction under 300°C and 50bar H2 pressure. However, the catalytic models were determined at initial reaction rates where the catalyst is assumed to be in its oxidic state. The set of elementary steps considered in Model 2 were: (22) Adsorption of GUA: GUA+M↔GUA-M Equilibrium K GUA (23) H2 Dissociative adsorption: H2 +2M↔2H*-M Equilibrium K H2 (24) Addition of H*: GUA-M+H*-M↔GUAH*-M+M Equilibrium K 3 (25) Addition of H*: GUAH*-M+H*-M↔Ph+MeOH+2M Rate constant K 4 The rate determining step of the reaction is assumed to be the addition of the second H atom, same as for Model 1. Thus, the reaction rate for Model 2 is given by the expression: (26) r GUA = k 4 C GUAH * − M C H * − M From Eqs. (23) and (24), we can deduce the concentration for C GUAH*−M and C H*−M, respectively. (27) C GUA H * − M = K 3 C H * − M C GUA − M C M (28) C H * − M = K H 2 1 / 2 C H 2 1 / 2 C M Substituting Eqs. (27) and (28) into (26): (29) r GUA = k 4 K 3 K H 2 C GUA − M C H 2 C M From Eq. (22) the concentration of C GUA−M can be deduced and substituted into Eq. (35) can be expressed by: (36) r GUA = k GUA K GUA C GUA C H 2 ( 1 + K GUA C GUA ) 2 where: k GUA = k 4 K 3 K H 2 ( C M ) 0 2 Linearizing Eq. (36), we get: (37) C GUA r GUA = 1 k GUA + K GUA C GUA k GUA K GUA C H 2 3.3.2.1 Corroboration of the kinetic model over ReOx/SiO2 To corroborate the proposed kinetic law for guaiacol conversion over the ReOx/SiO2 catalyst, the initial rate values from the linearized equation as a function of the initial guaiacol concentration (Eq. (37)) were plotted and shown in Fig. 6 . With respect to Model 2, the variation of catalytic activity with guaiacol concentration in the reaction mixture should be able to fit a straight line with a positive slope, which should cut the Y axis without passing through the origin. For the ReOx/SiO2 catalyst, the initial rate vs. guaiacol conversion line fits Model 2 which assumes the presence of one kind of active site, and follows a linear behavior and a correlation of 0.94614 (as can be seen in Fig. 6). Furthermore, this model allows us to explain the trend found in the catalytic activity when the concentration of guaiacol is increased. Unlike for the ReS2/SiO2 catalyst, where an increase in the conversion of guaiacol was observed even at high concentrations, the activity of the ReOx/SiO2 catalyst increased until a guaiacol concentration of 0.183molL−1 (Fig. 4(b)). This is obviously due to competitive adsorption between hydrogen and guaiacol on the active site of the catalyst, which is more prominent at high guaiacol concentration. Accordingly, the observed increase up to 0.183molL−1 and the subsequent decrease at higher concentrations was attributed to guaiacol probably adsorbing more strongly on the ReOx/SiO2 catalyst than the hydrogen, and thus limits the adsorption of H2 on the surface. However, at higher guaiacol concentrations, the expression ( 1 + K GUA C GUA ) 2 in Eq. (36) from Model 2 plays an important role because K GUA C GUA becomes very large, leading to a decrease in catalytic activity. Accordingly, these results confirm that guaiacol is strongly adsorbed on the active site on the ReOx/SiO2 catalyst, leading to a greater surface coverage of guaiacol and a decrease in the concentration of hydrogen adsorbed. This consequently leads to a decrease of guaiacol conversion, which confirms the competitive adsorption between guaiacol and H2, and explains the maximum observed activity, in agreement with Fig. 4(b). Therefore, the results clearly show that the conversion of guaiacol over the ReOx/SiO2 catalyst fits Model 2 while the ReS2/SiO2 did not (the inset of Fig. 6), corroborating the proposed kinetic Model 1. 4 Conclusion The conversion of guaiacol over ReS2/SiO2 and ReOx/SiO2 catalysts showed many differences in activity and selectivity. The ReOx/SiO2 catalyst displayed a higher activity and selectivity to deoxygenated products (mainly cyclohexane), while the ReS2/SiO2 catalyst was more selective towards the formation of phenol. The kinetic models developed showed that the ReOx/SiO2 and ReS2/SiO2 catalysts displayed different reaction mechanisms. The kinetic results obtained for the ReS2/SiO2 catalyst fitted a model assuming the presence of two distinct catalytic sites and hydrogen heterolytic dissociative adsorption (Model 1). On the contrary, the kinetic result for the ReOx/SiO2 catalyst was adjusted to a kinetic model involving a single kind of active site, and a homolytic dissociative adsorption of hydrogen (Model 2). This suggests that guaiacol and hydrogen adsorbed on the same active site on the ReOx/SiO2 catalyst. Therefore, a clear competition was observed between the reactants for the active site on the ReOx/SiO2 catalyst at high concentrations of guaiacol. The observed decrease of the catalytic activity was attributed to the higher adsorption of guaiacol which is probably more strongly adsorbed on the ReOx/SiO2 than the hydrogen. coredata.dc:description: The kinetics of guaiacol conversion over ReS2/SiO2 and ReOx/SiO2 catalysts in a batch reactor at 300°C and 5MPa hydrogen pressure was studied. The ReOx/SiO2 catalyst was more active and selective towards deoxygenated products (mainly cyclohexane), while the ReS2/SiO2 catalyst was more selective towards the formation of phenol. Langmuir–Hinshelwood kinetic models were developed in order to identify changes in the reaction mechanism with the ReOx/SiO2 and ReS2/SiO2 catalysts. The results for the guaiacol conversion over ReS2/SiO2 catalyst were fitted to a model that assumes the presence of two different kinds of active sites and that hydrogen adsorption is generated through heterolytic dissociation. The conversion of guaiacol over the ReOx/SiO2 catalyst was fitted to a model that assumes hydrogen adsorption via homolytic dissociation and a single catalytic site.
coredata.dc:title: Kinetic study of the conversion of 2-methoxyphenol over supported Re catalysts: Sulfide and oxide state
